unnormalised: Delhi Jal Board Announces New Tariff Hikes Effective 01/04/2024
normalised: Delhi Jal Board Announces New Tariff Hikes Effective First April two thousand and twenty four

unnormalised: The Delhi Jal Board (DJB) has announced a revised tariff structure for water and sewer charges, effective from April 1st, 2024. The decision, made during a board meeting held on 15/03/2024, aims to address the growing operational costs and infrastructure maintenance needs of the city’s water supply system. The new rates will impact domestic and commercial consumers across Delhi-NCR.
normalised: The Delhi Jal Board (D-J-B) has announced a revised tariff structure for water and sewer charges, effective from April first, two thousand and twenty four. The decision, made during a board meeting held on fifteenth March two thousand and twenty four, aims to address the growing operational costs and infrastructure maintenance needs of the city’s water supply system. The new rates will impact domestic and commercial consumers across Delhi-N-C-R.

unnormalised: Under the revised scheme, households consuming up to 20,000 liters of water per month will continue to receive a subsidy, maintaining the current rate of Rs. 0. The DJB spokesperson clarified that this measure is to safeguard the interests of economically weaker sections. However, for consumption exceeding 20000 liters, a graduated tariff will apply. For instance, usage between 20,001 and 30,000 liters will be charged at Rs. 5 per 1000 liters, a jump from the current rate of Rs. 3.
normalised: Under the revised scheme, households consuming up to twenty thousand liters of water per month will continue to receive a subsidy, maintaining the current rate of rupees zero. The D-J-B spokesperson clarified that this measure is to safeguard the interests of economically weaker sections. However, for consumption exceeding twenty thousand liters, a graduated tariff will apply. For instance, usage between twenty thousand one and thirty thousand liters will be charged at rupees five per one thousand liters, a jump from the current rate of rupees three.

unnormalised: Commercial establishments will see a more significant increase, with rates escalating by an average of 15%. Sewerage charges, previously fixed at 60% of the water bill, will now be calculated at 70%. This adjustment seeks to recover costs associated with sewage treatment and disposal. The DJB estimates this change will generate an additional revenue of Rs. 200 crore annually.
normalised: Commercial establishments will see a more significant increase, with rates escalating by an average of fifteen percent. Sewerage charges, previously fixed at sixty percent of the water bill, will now be calculated at seventy percent. This adjustment seeks to recover costs associated with sewage treatment and disposal. The D-J-B estimates this change will generate an additional revenue of rupees two hundred crore annually.

unnormalised: The DJB urges consumers to use water responsibly and adopt water-saving practices. Detailed information on the new tariffs, including a calculator for estimating monthly bills, is available on the DJB website: www.delhijalboard.nic.in. Consumers can also contact the helpline at 1916 for any queries related to their bills or water supply issues. They project a 10% decrease in water wastage as a result.
